docs.lead_paragraph: By some estimates, half or more of the 100 million emergency room visits Americans make each year are for problems, like colds, that are not urgent. Misuse of the emergency system can mean that patients genuinely needing emergency care will face long waits, and sometimes go without any care. A study released today suggests that part of the solution may lie in turning away some patients and giving them appointments the next day at a clinic. Writing in The Annals of Internal Medicine, researchers say that if patients are carefully screened, the practice appears safe.
docs.abstract: Annals of Internal Medicine study suggests that using deferral care for non-urgent emergency room visitors could improve patient care for those seriously ill; deferrals also offer individuals set appointment times rather than potentially lengthy emergency room waits; Dr Donna L Washington, lead researcher from University of California at Los Angeles, warns more reasearch is needed to monitor widespread effect of system on patient's care; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: By some estimates, half or more of the 100 million emergency room visits Americans make each year are for problems, like colds, that are not urgent. Misuse of the emergency system can mean that patients genuinely needing emergency care will face long...

docs.lead_paragraph: Neuroscientists have found an evocative solution to a classic problem: which is more important in shaping the human brain, nature or nurture? Their answer is complex. The brain is not primarily the product of genes, they say, but neither is it simply the sum of one's experiences. Rather, they say, each human brain is constructed of complex neural circuits that start taking shape before birth and continue to grow and change throughout life as genes and cells are influenced by environment, experience and culture.

headline.main: Brain Power: The Search For Origins

docs.abstract: Dr Terrence J Sejnowski, neuroscientist at Salk Institute, asserts that at birth our brains contain basic framework that, as we grow, dynamically changes through interaction and reaction of genes and environmental experiences; theory, termed cultural biology, contends that until brain matures environment actually assembles and changes brain's circuitry; chronology of debate between genetic and environmental theories (M)
docs.snippet: Neuroscientists have found an evocative solution to a classic problem: which is more important in shaping the human brain, nature or nurture?     Their answer is complex. The brain is not primarily the product of genes, they say, but neither is it...

docs.lead_paragraph: At a special gym here on the western edge of the county, a dozen or more women with bellies out to there kick up their heels, stretch and do step aerobics and other activities to stay in shape and acquire or preserve the stamina they will need to deliver their babies and care for them. Their instructor, Angelica Divinagracia, guided them until 10 days before she gave birth to her first child in April. She continues to work with those still pregnant, as well as a number of other postpartum women, who say their workouts at the West Hills Hospital and Medical Center PregnaGym leave them feeling better, physically and mentally.

headline.main: Latest Advice on Pregnancy: Keep On Kickin'

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on benefits of exercise for pregnant women and for health of fetus; Dr Raul Artal, principal author of latest advisory from American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, comments; general atmosphere and curriculum at West Hills Hospital and Medical Center's PregnaGym are outlined; specific conditions which preclude exercise during pregnancy are listed; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: At a special gym here on the western edge of the county, a dozen or more women with bellies out to there kick up their heels, stretch and do step aerobics and other activities to stay in shape and acquire or preserve the stamina they will need to...

keywords.value: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents who smoke may be encouraging their children to try smoking by asking them to do things like lighting their cigarettes or cleaning out their ashtrays, researchers reported yesterday. A study that looked at the children for a year concluded that they were at a minimum more likely to experiment with tobacco, the lead author, Dr. Rafael Laniado-Laborin, told a conference of American College of Chest Physicians in San Diego.
docs.abstract: Dr Rafael Laniardo-Laborin presents outcome of year-long smoking study at conference of Amercian College of Chest Physicians; study surveyed 292 middle school students with smoking parents and determined that children who perform tobacco related activities for their parents are more likely to take up smoking; activities called 'prompts,' include purchasing cigarettes, cleaning ashtrays and even lighting cigarettes, add to existing tendency of children of smokers to pick up habit (S)
docs.snippet: Parents who smoke may be encouraging their children to try smoking by asking them to do things like lighting their cigarettes or cleaning out their ashtrays, researchers reported yesterday.     A study that looked at the children for a year concluded...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who have the irregular heart rhythm known as atrial fibrillation are known to have a greater risk for strokes. A new study suggests one way that doctors can make sure these patients get the help they need. Writing in the current issue of the journal Stroke, researchers said emergency room workers should be trained to ask patients who come in with problems related to atrial fibrillation whether they are taking blood-thinning drugs that can reduce their chance of stroke.
docs.abstract: Dr Phillip A Scott, assistant professor of emergency medicine at University of Michigan, authors research published in journal Stroke that suggests use of blood thinners for reduction of ischemic stroke in emergency room patients with atrial fibrillation (S)
docs.snippet: People who have the irregular heart rhythm known as atrial fibrillation are known to have a greater risk for strokes. A new study suggests one way that doctors can make sure these patients get the help they need.    Writing in the current issue of...

docs.lead_paragraph: At 6:30 in the morning, a strapping teenager on the cusp of manhood can look an awful lot like a newborn puppy, with eyes that won't open and a powerful instinct to curl up under something warm. Is this the same person who swore he wasn't tired at 10:30 the night before while he traded instant messages with six different friends at once, and who will probably do it again tonight?

headline.main: Sleep Is One Thing Missing in Busy Teenage Lives

docs.abstract: Brown University sleep researcher Dr Mary Carskadon discusses variety of reasons teenagers need more sleep and defends rationale for shifting school schedules to later start times; research at University of Minnesota and Navy's Great Lakes Academy supports theory; National Sleep Foundation says sleep deprivation has many adverse consequences in lives of young people; cites examples; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: At 6:30 in the morning, a strapping teenager on the cusp of manhood can look an awful lot like a newborn puppy, with eyes that won't open and a powerful instinct to curl up under something warm.     Is this the same person who swore he wasn't tired...

docs.lead_paragraph: Russia's decision to blow an aerosolized form of a powerful narcotic through the ventilation system of a theater to end a hostage crisis in Moscow late last month raised anew an inevitable and terrifying question: what if a terrorist unleashed a potentially lethal chemical in this country? Particularly since Sept. 11, many public health officials have worried about possible bioterrorist attacks with chemicals, smallpox or other microbes. Now, the use of the narcotic fentanyl has refocused attention on those concerns, particularly in light of Russian doctors' criticism that their government did not organize enough rescue workers to give victims an antidote, naloxone.

headline.main: Moscow Toll Revives Concerns Over Chemical Attacks

docs.abstract: Moscow (Russia) theater hostage crisis reemphasizes need for health organizations to be prepared for all kinds of possible terrorist attacks with lethal chemicals; describes various reactions, possible treatments, timing of exposure to different agents and information about decontamination efforts; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Russia's decision to blow an aerosolized form of a powerful narcotic through the ventilation system of a theater to end a hostage crisis in Moscow late last month raised anew an inevitable and terrifying question: what if a terrorist unleashed a...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Feng Shui and Health: The Anatomy of a Home,'' by Nancy SantoPietro, Three Rivers Press, $15.95. Does the floor plan of your home or office make you physically ill? Are you so sensitive to the ''energy'' in your bedroom that you're stressed out and can't sleep?
docs.abstract: Nancy SantoPietro book Feng Shui and Health gives advice on how to create healthy home or office; Feng Shui shapes individual environments, invites healing forces and promotes physical benefits; photo (S)

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH Daniel Kahneman; On Profit, Loss and the Mysteries of the Mind

docs.abstract: Erica Goode interviews Nobel prize winner Dr Daniel Kahneman about his groundbreaking theories of human behavior as they relate to economics; collaboration with Professor Dr Amos Tversky discussed; work of Kahneman and Tversky provided undergirding for behavioral economics approach, developed by Dr Richard Thaler; Kahneman and Tversky challenged long assumed theory by economists that beliefs and decisions conform to logical rules; demonstrated that people often made illogical choices and irrational judgements; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Jivamukti Yoga,'' by Sharon Gannon and David Life, Ballantine Books, $16. The readers of ''Jivamukti Yoga'' (roughly translated from Sanskrit as ''individual soul liberation yoga'') should be aware, as the authors say, that the aim of yoga is not a better body or a calmer mind, even though the practices may improve one's body or calm the mind. ''The aim is enlightenment, the state in which everything fits together,'' they say.
docs.abstract: Book Jivamukti Yoga, written by Sharon Gannon and David Life, gives extremely detailed description of their theory of yoga for enlightenment; gives advice, illustrates yoga postures, and supplies extensive glossary to teach enthusiasts from all backgrounds and experiences; photo (S)
